elbert.View Type: 360° panoramic views from alpine tundra; vast vistas of Colorado's high country.
elbert.Best Seasons to Hike: Summer and early fall – avoid monsoon thunderstorms; winter ascents for experts only.
elbert.Exposure Level: High – long stretches above treeline with frequent wind and lightning hazard.
elbert.Terrain Character: Forest or tundra approaches leading to rocky slopes and loose scree near the summit.
elbert.Scramble Sections: Moderate to strenuous scrambling on talus; some peaks require navigation around cliffs.
elbert.Water Availability: Limited – small streams near trailhead; little to no water above treeline.
elbert.Cell Reception Quality: Variable; often poor in remote basins.
elbert.Nearby Notable Features: Wildflower meadows, alpine lakes and neighboring 14ers within the same range.
elbert.Weather Exposure Rating: High – sudden storms, snow and lightning are common in high alpine environments.
elbert.Emergency Bailout Options: Descend the ascent route; some peaks offer connecting ridges but no short bailouts.
elbert.Most Common Trailhead: Established 14er trailhead parking areas (varies by peak).
elbert.Parking Notes: Parking often fills early; some trailheads require fees or permits.
elbert.Dog Friendly: Varies by peak – many class 1 and 2 routes are dog friendly; avoid technical summits.
elbert.Summit Marker Type: Rock cairn or survey benchmark – few have signs.
elbert.Flora/Environment Zones: Aspen and pine forests, subalpine spruce–fir, krummholz and alpine tundra above treeline.

belford.Exposure Level: High – long stretches above treeline with frequent wind and lightning hazard.
belford.Terrain Character: Forest or tundra approaches leading to rocky slopes and loose scree near the summit.
belford.Scramble Sections: Moderate to strenuous scrambling on talus; some peaks require navigation around cliffs.
belford.Water Availability: Limited – small streams near trailhead; little to no water above treeline.
belford.Cell Reception Quality: Variable; often poor in remote basins.
belford.Nearby Notable Features: Wildflower meadows, alpine lakes and neighboring 14ers within the same range.
belford.Weather Exposure Rating: High – sudden storms, snow and lightning are common in high alpine environments.
belford.Emergency Bailout Options: Descend the ascent route; some peaks offer connecting ridges but no short bailouts.
belford.Most Common Trailhead: Established 14er trailhead parking areas (varies by peak).
belford.Parking Notes: Parking often fills early; some trailheads require fees or permits.
belford.Dog Friendly: Varies by peak – many class 1 and 2 routes are dog friendly; avoid technical summits.
belford.Summit Marker Type: Rock cairn or survey benchmark – few have signs.
belford.Flora/Environment Zones: Aspen and pine forests, subalpine spruce–fir, krummholz and alpine tundra above treeline.

huron-peak.Summit Marker Type: Rock cairn or survey benchmark – few have signs.
huron-peak.Flora/Environment Zones: Aspen and pine forests, subalpine spruce–fir, krummholz and alpine tundra above treeline.

holy-cross.View Type: 360° panoramic views from alpine tundra; vast vistas of Colorado's high country.
holy-cross.Best Seasons to Hike: Summer and early fall – avoid monsoon thunderstorms; winter ascents for experts only.
holy-cross.Exposure Level: High – long stretches above treeline with frequent wind and lightning hazard.
holy-cross.Terrain Character: Forest or tundra approaches leading to rocky slopes and loose scree near the summit.
holy-cross.Scramble Sections: Moderate to strenuous scrambling on talus; some peaks require navigation around cliffs.
holy-cross.Water Availability: Limited – small streams near trailhead; little to no water above treeline.
holy-cross.Cell Reception Quality: Variable; often poor in remote basins.
holy-cross.Nearby Notable Features: Wildflower meadows, alpine lakes and neighboring 14ers within the same range.
holy-cross.Weather Exposure Rating: High – sudden storms, snow and lightning are common in high alpine environments.
holy-cross.Emergency Bailout Options: Descend the ascent route; some peaks offer connecting ridges but no short bailouts.
holy-cross.Most Common Trailhead: Established 14er trailhead parking areas (varies by peak).
